entry.title: When opening a new window from an existing window, new window is bigger
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Open a window 2. Press Ctrl+N several times 3. compare the size of the first window and the last window
# Problem Description New window should be the same size as last window
# Summary When opening a new window from an existing window, new window is bigger
# Additional Data Category: UI \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: Tests are failing: session_manager_state_waiter.cc(54): Failed\nRunLoop::Run() timed out. Timeout set at ProxyRunTestOnMainThreadLoop@content/public/test/browser_test...
entry.content:
This bug is for all test failures where the primary error message is similiar to the following (ignoring numbers and hexadecimal values): session_manager_state_waiter.cc(54): Failed\nRunLoop::Run() timed out. Timeout set at ProxyRunTestOnMainThreadLoop@content/public/test/browser_test_base.cc:851.
The following test(s) were observed to have matching failures at this time (at most five examples listed): - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/AuthFlowsLoginAddExistingUserTest.GaiaPasswordNotChanged - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/AuthFlowsLoginAddExistingUserTest.GaiaPassworRecoverydNotChanged - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/AuthFlowsLoginReauthTest.GaiaPasswordRecoveryNotChanged - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/AuthFlowsLoginReauthTest.GaiaPasswordNotChanged - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/AccessibilityManagerUserTypeTest.BrailleWhenLoggedIn/UserTypeInstantiation.2
These test failures are causing problem(s) which require your attention, including: - many gardened builders are failing
See current problems, failure examples and more in LUCI Analysis at: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/p/chromium/rules/6eb450b84e4b55486085f78b2cb59a39
How to action this bug: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#new-bug-filed Provide feedback: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#feedback Was this bug filed in the wrong component? See: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#component-selection

entry.title: favicon appears in MV2 extension but not with new MV3 favicon API
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Open the MV2-style link chrome://favicon/http://reddit.com/ and note the reddit favicon appears. 2. Open the MV3-style link chrome-extension://EXTENSION_ID/_favicon/?pageUrl=http%3A%2F%2Freddit.com%2F&size=16 (you must replace the EXTENSION_ID text). Note a grey icon appears, indicating the reddit favicon is not present.
# Problem Description A favicon that appears in an MV2 extension does not appear after converting the extension to MV3.
# Summary favicon appears in MV2 extension but not with new MV3 favicon API
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Not sure - I don't know
#### Does this work in other browsers? Yes - This is just a Chrome problem
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: [ozone wayland] gl=egl-angle,angle=vulkan is not an allowed implementation
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Run Chromium on ozone wayland with the gl=egl-angle,angle=vulkan flags 2. Requested GL implementation (gl=egl-angle,angle=vulkan) not found in allowed implementations: [(gl=egl-angle,angle=opengl),(gl=egl-angle,angle=opengles),(gl=egl-gles2,angle=none),(gl=egl-angle,angle=swiftshader)] 3. Exiting GPU process due to errors during initialization
# Problem Description --use-angle=vulkan is required to get working vaapi acceleration with AMD cards: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/mesa/mesa/-/merge_requests/26165 Unfortunately it only works on X11/XWayland because gl=egl-angle,angle=vulkan is not a supported combination on ozone wayland.
# Summary [ozone wayland] gl=egl-angle,angle=vulkan is not an allowed implementation
# Custom Questions #### Please select a label to classify your issue: Type-Feature - Request for new or improved features
# Additional Data Category: Other \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: Regression: Crash when clicking user profile icon in browser context
Custom autonomous elements with html that has nested declarative shadowroot templates are ignored.
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Create a custom autonomous element 2. When setting .innerHTML of element, include markup (instances) of other custom nested elements 3. Use declarative shadowrootmode tempates on some of the nested custom elements
# Problem Description The custom autonomous element will render, but each of it's nested instances of elements that used declarative shadowrootmode templates fail to be parsed and treated as lightdom nodes instead. The solution that fixes this is using .setHTMLUnsafe(htmlStr) in my custom component which then works as expected.
Even if i crafted a <template shadowrootmode> on the fly and tried to set it on an element (innerhtml or appendchild as fragment), it will be ignored unless setHTMLUnsafe() is used.
Is this correct behavior?
# Summary Custom autonomous elements with html that has nested declarative shadowroot templates are ignored.
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Blink>DOM
#### Does this work in other browsers? Not sure - I don't know
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: Page focus on <body> when clicking on back button and not last active element
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Go to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/History_API/Working_with_the_History_API 2. Search for "single-page application" 3. First result is a link, click on it. 4. Click on back button. 5. check value of `document.activeElement` (it will say `<body>`)
# Problem Description I couldn't find a specification in the Chromium pages yet, but even if there are no formal / official specification documents, I presume there are tests that prescribe how the back button should work?
Asked a question online (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/78319359, https://software.codidact.com/posts/291296) to make a legacy web application more accessible for screen reader (JAWS, in this case) users, and the gist is that `history.scrollRestoration` (in the HTML spec's History API) is responsible in part: if it is set to "auto", then "the user agent is responsible for restoring the scroll position upon navigation".
After some testing without JAWS using document.activeElement in the browser consoles, Chrome (Version 122.0.6261.112 (Official Build) (arm64)) does not retain scroll information and simply focuses on the body when jumping back in history.
What I'm trying to figure out whether the behaviour in my tests is how it supposed to work or is this a regression?
Appreciatively, Attila
# Summary Page focus on <body> when clicking on back button and not last active element
# Additional Data Category: UI \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: When specific code is executed, there is a symptom where WebGPU is not supported in all windows.
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. https://webgpufundamentals.org/webgpu/lessons/webgpu-compute-shaders-histogram-part-2.html 2. Execute second samples of the link above. 3. Open new tap or window. 4. Open developer tools, and console 5. check there is gpu object with console.log(navigator.gpu) 6. try to make adapter with const adapter = await navigator.gpu.requestAdapter(); 7. Check it is null, and cannot make device with adapter.requestDevice() 8. Close all brower windows, and open again 9. Repeat 5~6, then it works well now
# Problem Description https://webgpufundamentals.org/webgpu/lessons/webgpu-compute-shaders-histogram-part-2.html
After running specific code (the second and third examples from the linked page), an issue occurs where WebGPU is not supported in all other browser tabs and windows, as well as in new windows. Before running this code, everything worked normally, and the issue is resolved if all browser windows are closed and reopened.
The exact description of the issue where WebGPU is not supported is: While the navigator.gpu object is recognized properly, the requestAdapter method returns null instead of a device.
# Summary When specific code is executed, there is a symptom where WebGPU is not supported in all windows.
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Blink>WebGPU
#### Does this work in other browsers? Not sure - I don't know
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: Chromium will not query v4l2 decoder with device path other than /dev/video-dec0
entry.content:
From [this cr](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5293184) chromium will only query /dev/video-dec0 to detect v4l2 decoder. But there are platforms has v4l2 decoder devices with name other than /dev/video-dec0.
For example:
1, On qcom sm8250 platform, both decoder and encoder are under the same devicetree node, and decoder will get initialized with name "/dev/video0" or "/dev/video1" randomly, so decoder may get initialized as "/dev/video-dec1" for linux.
2, On rockchip rk3588 platform, there are multi v4l2 stateless decoders: ``` $ LC_ALL=C ls -l /sys/class/video4linux/ total 0 lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 0 Apr 13 14:25 video0 -> ../../devices/platform/fdb80000.rga/video4linux/video0 lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 0 Apr 13 14:25 video1 -> ../../devices/platform/fdb50000.video-codec/video4linux/video1 lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 0 Apr 13 14:25 video2 -> ../../devices/platform/fdc70000.video-codec/video4linux/video2 ```
And there is a v4l2m2m rga device initialized by /dev/video0. This is a quick fix patch: https://paste.armbian.com/raw/becoqedeku
